Column No : 208

ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICE

(Resignations)

     1.  Mr Siew Kum Hong asked the Prime Minister and Minister for Finance for each of the years from 2004 to 2006 (a) how many officers resigned from the Administrative Service and what resignation rate did that represent; (b) of these resignations, how many Administrative Officers cited higher pay in a new job as the main reason or one of the main reasons; and (c) how many Administrative Officers were asked to resign for reasons related to non-performance.

     The Minister for Defence (Mr Teo Chee Hean) (for the Prime Minister and Minister for Finance):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of Administrative Officers who resigned from the Administrative Service in 2004, 2005 and 2006 were four, 10 and seven respectively.  This corresponds to the resignation rates of 2%, 4% and 3% respectively.  If we include Management Associates, who are the officers being tested for suitability for the Administrative Service, the resignation numbers are larger, but, of course, the base is larger as well.  The total number of Administrative Officers and Management Associates who resigned in 2004, 2005 and 2006 were four, 14 and 12 respectively.  This corresponds to the resignation rates of 1%, 4% and 3% respectively.

 

     Administrative Officers leave the Service for various reasons, and we may often not be able to ascertain exactly the real reasons for their departure.  Some indicated that they would like to further their studies while others want to have a change of career.  Some of those who leave for jobs in the private sector enjoy a pay increase in their new jobs.  

 

     The Administrative Service has very stringent retention standards.  Officers are appraised annually and are expected to have the potential to hold at least Deputy Secretary or CEO level jobs.  Those who do not meet the mark are asked to leave the Service but they could remain in other schemes in the Civil Service if they wish and if there are suitable jobs for them.  Over the last three years, a total of 13 Administrative Officers left the Service on such grounds, ie, they were managed out of the Service.  Of these, eight officers left the Public Service. The other five transferred to join other schemes within the Public Service where they continue to contribute to the public service.

     Mr Siew Kum Hong (Nominated Member):  Mr Speaker, Sir, I would just like to ask the Minister how many Administrative Officers are there in grades MR4 and above between SR9 and MR4 and on Timescales. 

     Mr Teo Chee Hean:  Sir, I do not carry the numbers in my head.  If the Member could submit a Question, I would be happy to answer it.

FORMULA 1 RACING IN SINGAPORE

     The following Question stood in the name of Mdm Ho Geok Choo -

 

     2.  To ask the Minister for Trade and Industry what is his Ministry's position on the recent comment by the Malaysian Youth and Sports Minister that Singapore should not establish Formula 1 racing in view of the fact that it will be competing with Malaysia.

     Er Lee Bee Wah (Ang Mo Kio):  Question No. 2, Sir.

     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr S Iswaran) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry):  Mr Speaker, Sir, it has been widely reported in the media that Mr Bernie Ecclestone, Chief Executive of the Formula One Group, is keen to increase the number of races per season from 17 currently to 20.  So, just like Abu Dhabi and Seoul, the possible addition of a race in the F1 calendar in Singapore would not necessarily be at the expense of any of the existing races.  Moreover, we do understand from public information sources that Sepang’s contract provides for a race to be held each year until 2010.

 

     Having said that, it is natural for some competition to exist between all F1 races.  However, we do not see competition arising or being disadvantageous just because of geographical proximity.  In fact, there are several F1 races that take place in the same region, such as those in Monaco and Monza, which is in Italy, and in Fuji in the Shizuoka Prefecture of Japan, and Shanghai.  There are also several other factors that should be taken into account.  For example, each race is unique in terms of its character and circuit design.  Sepang has a dedicated circuit, while we are looking at a street circuit in Singapore.  Should Singapore host the F1 Grand Prix, there will indeed be much scope for both countries’ events to complement each other.

     Er Lee Bee Wah:  Sir, if that is how Singapore sees opportunities for our neighbours with this win-win situation and we can work with each other, would our neighbour respond in the same positive manner with this mentality and this desired outcome?

     Mr Iswaran:  Mr Speaker, Sir, based on media reports, the Chairman of the Sepang International Circuit, Mr Mokhzani, has, in fact, said that he welcomes the proposition of a race in Singapore because he sees this as creating a greater level of interest in the region and more avenues for collaboration.  So, taking that as a benchmark from the private sector in Malaysia, I would assume that they do see the potential for a win-win collaboration, as the Member has put it.

     Er Lee Bee Wah:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I think we also read from the newspapers that there are quite a number of Malaysian politicians making negative remarks on this.  So, has the MOS had any opportunity to have a discussion with them?

     Mr Iswaran:  No, I have not had any personal discussion with any of the particular politicians the Member was referring to.

Column No : 212

UPGRADING OF ONE-ROOM HDB FLATS

(Temporary units for tenants)

     3.  Mr Siew Kum Hong asked the Minister for National Development in view of the situation of some tenants of one-room flats having to sleep in corridors and common areas when their flats are being upgraded (a) what are the HDB’s reasons for not permitting vacant units to be used on a temporary basis; (b) whether this situation has been encountered in previous upgradings; and (c) what measures will be taken to prevent a recurrence in future upgrading projects.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman) (for the Minister for National Development):  Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank the Member for this opportunity to clarify media reports in mid-March that the ongoing upgrading of a block of rental flats in Toa Payoh had inconvenienced some residents.

 

     The particular rental block is being upgraded under Project LIFE.  LIFE stands for Lift Improvement and Facilities Enhancement.  This is a programme implemented by HDB for one-room rental blocks where there is a high concentration of elderly residents.  It seeks to improve the physical living conditions of the elderly tenants through lift upgrading and the installation of elder-friendly features, such as support handbars and the Alert Alarm System.  It is fully paid for by the Government.

 

     When these upgrading works are going on in a rental block, HDB implements a host of measures to reduce inconvenience to residents.  The contractors can work inside the flat only from 9.00 am to 5.00 pm during weekdays.   They have to ensure that the flat is cleared up at the end of each day.  There is an air-conditioned area for affected residents to rest during these working hours.  Temporary toilets and storage space are also made available.  And the upgrading is done in batches so that these communal facilities are sufficient for the affected residents’ use.
 
     Sir, since 1993, HDB has upgraded 38 rental blocks under Project LIFE and, in all these projects, no tenant has been forced to sleep in the corridors as a result of the upgrading works.  One of the newspaper articles showed a picture of a man sleeping at the common corridor of his rental block.  HDB investigated and found that he was sleeping outside on his own accord.  The upgrading works at his unit has not even started.  We have informed the newspaper that they had inadvertently misled their readers by using the picture in the wrong context. 

 

     HDB does exercise flexibility in cases of residents with serious medical or mobility problems and will arrange for such households to be shifted to a vacant unit.  However, in the recent case, the resident who complained to the press did not fall into this category.  He had asked for a vacant unit to store his belongings.  He was not happy that he had to store it in the allocated storage space provided.  HDB could not accede to his request, so he complained to the press.

Column No : 213

CHILDLESS SINGAPOREAN WOMEN

(Financial support for fertility treatment)

     4.  Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports whether the Government will consider giving a special grant or other forms of financial support for childless Singaporean women who are seeking medical treatment to have children.

     The Minister of State for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon) (for the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports):  Mr Speaker, Sir, some couples who want children but have difficulties conceiving would turn to Assisted Conception Procedures (ACP).  As part of the 2004 Marriage and Parenthood package, couples undergoing ACP can now use up to $6,000, $5,000 and $4,000 from their own or their spouse’s Medisave for the first, second and third treatment cycles respectively.  For the majority of couples who choose to undergo ACP at public hospitals, these withdrawal limits would cover the bulk of the treatment cost.

 

     Although greater financial support for fertility treatment will make ACP more affordable for couples who have difficulty conceiving, unfortunately, the reality is that no amount of financial support is able to increase the success rate of ACP. 

 

     As fertility declines with age, what is needed are upstream efforts to raise awareness on the narrowing fertility window as one ages and the risks associated with delayed childbearing.  I am happy to report that our public education efforts have reaped some results.  From my Ministry’s 2006 survey of 3,000 married respondents, 94% are aware that it gets more difficult for couples to conceive as they get older, up from 89% in 2004.  However, more can and must be done to raise awareness level and to transform awareness into a change in attitude and behaviour.  My Ministry has and will continue to partner medical experts to spread this important message.

     Er Lee Bee Wah:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the sentiment among the childless couples is that they have already sacrificed their time in going through ACP.  So they are asking whether it is possible to give them financial aid.  They are aware that the CPF can be used.  But what they are asking for is financial aid, because they have sacrificed their time.  The end result is that what they are doing is beneficial for the country.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I do agree with the hon. Member.  But Medisave, as all of us know, is limited.  We also have to safeguard our old-age medical benefits.  The average cost for IVF is about $6,000 to $8,000 at KK Hospital.  If you use Medisave, the first time is $6,000, the second is $5,000 and the third time is $4,000.  I think this is quite sufficient to cover most of the costs.  Let us allow this scheme to carry on first and we will monitor the situation.

     Mr Hri Kumar Nair (Bishan-Toa Payoh):  Sir, firstly, may I know the number of couples who are currently undergoing ACP.  Secondly, in relation to the survey results that the MOS just mentioned, may I know the age of the couples surveyed?

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  Sir, the number of women who undergo ACP is about 1,700 a year.  But based on the number of cycles, it is about 2,000-over annually.  The success rate corresponds to their age.  For women below 30, the success rate is about 26%.  For those who are in their early 30s, it is about 25%.  For those beyond 40, it is very, very low.  It is actually below 10%.  So the success rate goes down as the women get older.  As for the survey of these 3,000 respondents, I can tell him that most of them are in the region of 30s.

Column No : 215

ELDER ABUSE

     5.  Assoc. Prof. Kalyani K Mehta asked the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (a) what are the last three years' statistics on elder abuse in Singapore, with a breakdown according to age, gender, relationship with perpetrator, marital status, ethnicity and citizenship; (b) what is the number of times the Elder Protection Team was activated in the past year; and (c) whether there is an elder abuse protocol put in place by his Ministry.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (for the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports):  Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank Assoc. Prof. Kalyani Mehta for this Question and for her concern about elder abuse.

 

     The number of reported elder abuse cases in the past three years has been stable.  There were 186 cases in 2006, 181 in 2005 and 194 in 2004.  On average, 64% of the reported cases were elderly women and 66% of the abused elderly persons were 70 years old and above.  In 70% of the cases, the perpetrators were the victims' own children.  The majority of the abused elderly persons were Singaporeans who were married with children.  The ethnic breakdown of the cases is similar to Singapore's racial mix.

 

 


    Any elderly person who is reported to be abused will be attended to.  Depending on the first point of contact, the victim may be attended to by a medical social worker if the person is at the hospital or by a social worker from a Family Service Centre if he or she is in the community.  When MCYS is informed of any abuse, our Ministry staff will also attend to the elderly person. 
 
    The Elder Protection Team is activated only for cases which are more complex. This team, spearheaded by TRANS Centre (a voluntary welfare organisation specialising in family violence work) consists of professionals with knowledge in geriatrics, psychiatry, law and social work.  In the past year, the Elder Protection Team attended to seven new cases and reviewed five cases. 

  

     There is a robust protocol in place to manage elder abuse cases.  A victim of abuse can approach a social worker, the hospital, the police or the court. Each of these agencies and individuals has been trained to provide assistance, make referrals to relevant agencies or activate the Elder Protection Team whenever necessary.  We appreciate that an elderly person may be reluctant to seek help.  Social workers, friends and grassroots leaders therefore play an important part in identifying elderly persons that need help and refer them to Family Service Centres, which can then follow up.

     Assoc. Prof. Kalyani K Mehta (Nominated Member):  Thank you for the answer.  I need to further clarify.  From my knowledge, there was a message once that Mr Chan Soo Sen made at the beginning of a symposium on family networking on violence. He said that approximately 100 cases were seen per year.  So, if we compare these statistics with those that he showed at that symposium, I believe there could be an upward trend.

 

    Two, I would like to find out what is the definition of complex cases which was just mentioned.

      Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  Mr Speaker, Sir, if we refer to the numbers, for 2004, it was 194; 2005, it was 181; and 2006, it was 186. So it is quite stable.  But when we come to the factors, like I mentioned just now, most of the cases were actually abuse by their own children - over 40% by sons; over 20% by daughters; and about 12% by their own spouses.  So they are not outsiders. For these cases, like I have said, we have a protocol. We work very closely with the Police, hospitals and the Family Service Centres. When an elderly person or a friend refers the case to us, the social workers will be involved.  The social workers conduct risk assessment, work out safety plans and provide counselling.  Fortunately, for over 50% of the cases, after counselling, both sides were quite happy to work with each other again.  Actually, 90% of them still stay at the same place.  Only 10% have looked for alternative care or gone to institutional care. 

 

     Of course, besides this protocol, some also went direct to the police or court. Some have applied for Personal Protection Order (PPO). The worst cases would be those who apply under the Maintenance of Parents Act to seek help for shelter and crisis homes.  For some of them, we can even refer them to welfare homes if their children really cannot afford it.  Most of the reasons for getting into trouble are chronic or long-term sicknesses like Parkinson's, dementia, and so on.  I think the Chinese have a saying, "If you are sick for too long, there are no filial children."  Anyway, the point is that now, we also work with some VWOs.  I am sure Assoc. Prof. Mehta knows that we give the caregivers support as well.  It is not just on why they become angry and abuse the elderly, but we also get relief for them and get the VWOs to train and give them support. We found that most of these people who abuse their parents are those who depend on the aged for financial support.  They themselves do not do very well financially and so there is some relationship tension.  We will do our best to work with the VWOs closely to help both sides to better understand each other.

     Assoc. Prof. Kalyani K Mehta:  I mentioned that in the period prior to 2002, for five years, the statistics were about 100 cases a year. Would she agree that for the numbers that she has cited, there may be an upward trend that you see?

 

    Secondly, I want to know whether these statistics are compiled from the courts as well or it is mainly the VWOs that comprised these statistics.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:   I do agree that there is a slow increase.  I am sure she knows that our society is ageing.  At this moment, it is still quite stable but we can foresee that it is ageing.  Therefore, my Ministry and the VWOs also work towards planning for more services and areas on how to support the aged and their families.  I am sure Mr Lim Boon Heng, in charge of the Inter-Ministry Committee, and the Government are already paying attention to this. 

 

     I mentioned just now that for the protocol, we would involve the police, hospitals and families. After all these processes, some of them still refer them to the courts for a Personal Protection Order (PPO). Also, some of the cases, according to the court, went direct to the courts.  The courts so far have not given us the figures on how many were referred by us and how many were direct from the courts.  But the total number for 2006 was 125.  I assume some were referred from the 186 cases but some were direct from outside.

     Dr Fatimah Lateef (Marine Parade):  I would like to ask the Minister of State if she can clarify the numbers that she mentioned. Were they just the physical abuse of the elderly or do they also include things like financial abuse and psychological abuse of the elderly which we know happen in society as well?

 

   The second part is whether MCYS would like to consider embarking on an awareness campaign because, unlike child abuse and domestic violence, elderly abuse is something which is a bit quieter and needs a bit of enhancement and society as well.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon:  Actually, physical abuse represents about 33% and psychological abuse about 17%, and financial abuse is not so high, at 13%.  So I think physical abuse is still the highest. Definitely, public awareness is very important.  I mentioned just now that we would work with quite a number of VWOs.  We also set up training courses for the caregivers and their family members. At the same time, we also distribute some of the pamphlets to tell them how to handle the situation.  If they really need help, there is also the helpline.  Sometime ago, the Member mentioned that we should improve on the service of the helpline.  The Minister has already instructed us to do so.

Column No : 220

STUDENTS FROM SPECIAL ASSISTANCE PLAN SCHOOLS

(Integration)

     6.  Dr Fatimah Lateef asked the Minister for Education whether there are plans to further integrate students from the Special Assistance Plan schools into the wider, multicultural group of students from other schools in Singapore.

     The Minister of State for Education (Mr Gan Kim Yong) (for the Minister for Education):  Mr Speaker, it is always a pleasure to answer questions in the House.

 

    The Ministry of Education established the Special Assistance Plan, or SAP schools, in 1979 for two purposes.  Firstly, to keep alive the best traditions and ethos of old Chinese schools in a few selected schools, so as to inculcate traditional Chinese values and social discipline in a number of our top students.  Secondly, to encourage a number of our academically able and linguistically talented students to study both Chinese and English at the first language level.

 

     Today, our SAP schools continue to play a key role in nurturing a core group of bilingual Singaporeans who are well versed in the Chinese language and culture, with a deep understanding of their heritage, and who are also well poised to grasp opportunities in the emerging China market.  This is a strength of our system that we will continue to preserve going forward.    

 

     SAP schools are keenly aware that they need to work doubly hard to create opportunities for their students to interact with students from other ethnic groups.  They do so in a variety of forms - from twinning with non-SAP schools with a multi-racial composition to taking part in joint activities with non-SAP schools and community organisations which serve non-Chinese or multi-racial communities.  An example is the twinning arrangement between Ai Tong School, which is a Primary SAP school, and Pierce Secondary School.  Primary 4 pupils from Ai Tong who are weak in Mathematics and English receive tutoring help from non-Chinese students from Pierce Secondary.  Similarly, the Secondary 3 students in Chung Cheng High School (Main) run a Conversational Chinese Programme for Primary 5 non-Chinese students from Geylang Methodist Primary School.

 

      SAP schools also actively celebrate the different ethnic festivals and leverage on these occasions to deepen their students' understanding of other races and cultures.  Non-Chinese students from neighbouring schools are invited to join in for these events.  For instance, Anglican High celebrates Chinese New Year and Racial Harmony Day annually together with Damai Secondary School and Changkat Changi Secondary School. 

 

     Going forward, MOE and the SAP schools will continue to actively explore and create more opportunities for SAP students to interact with students from other ethnic groups.

     Dr Fatimah Lateef:  Thank you very much for the answer.  I would just like to ask one supplementary question.  Will there be a possibility to consider some kind of formal interactive programme or integration programme between uni-cultural schools, basically SAP schools, versus maybe perhaps madrasah schools?  Because a kind of a long-term relationship between two types of schools would probably be good in developing tolerance and understanding of our multi-cultural and multi-racial society.

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry has adopted the approach of top-down support for ground-up initiatives, ie, we encourage the schools to evolve and develop their own initiatives and programmes because by doing so, we give the schools a greater sense of ownership to the programmes that they have developed, and we encourage them to do so by providing them with the necessary support. Therefore, we would like to encourage a diversity of different programmes and activities.  Also, students will learn from different ways. So we encourage them to have different forms of integration programmes, rather than to formalise them and make it a formal programme.  We would prefer to encourage them to have their own ideas so that they will be more effective in inculcating this multi-racial culture within the school.

    Mr Zaqy Mohamad (Hong Kah):   I would like to ask the Minister whether the students from SAP schools could truly benefit from multi-culturalism at the programme level as opposed to a daily interaction basis.

    Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Mr Speaker, in fact, some of the programmes are long-term programmes and they interact quite regularly.  Let me give you an example. Hwa Chong Institution, for example, works very closely with its neighbourhood schools in terms of different cultural programmes.  One example is West Spring Secondary and Bukit Panjang Government High.  For these schools, they actually practise music together.  In Hwa Chong, there is a Chinese orchestra.  They have 24 festive drums as well as wushu. And from March to June, they will practise together with students from both schools. This culminates in a joint performance at the Racial Harmony Day in July. So they actually meet each other quite regularly within these three to four months.  They practise together, get to know each other, learn from each other, and then they jointly perform together at the Racial Harmony Day.

     Practice 1.  Set up an independent senior salaries review body comprising independent representatives from various key sectors in Singapore.  The principle of not writing one's own pay cheque is very key in addressing public disquiet on this issue.  The United Kingdom Senior Salaries Review Body, which proposes political and civil service pay, for instance, comprises senior executives from the private sector, HR and finance consultancy, academia and so forth.

     Compensation best practice dictates that there be a clear line of sight between one's pay packet and his direct performance.  In the case of public servants, I believe that performance-based pay can tie in to at least three tiers:  (1) country's performance, not just economic; (2) each Ministry's performance; and (3) each individual's performance.

     Practice 4.  Adopt a broader band pay range for each position that we are talking about, to cater to appropriate salary levels for incumbents ranging from those with entry-level skills to those critical skills experts or long-term outstanding performers.  Hence, hypothetically using $1.2 million as a mid point for a Minister's pay and a minimum-to-maximum spread of 60%, the minimum pay for entry-level Minister can be $840,000, or 30% below mid point; a mature performer gets $1.2 million and a consistent top performer gets close to $1.6 million, or 30% above mid point.  So, adopt a broader band pay range for each position.

     I do agree with Mr Lim Biow Chuan and Mr Siew Kum Hong that it is indeed an honour and privilege to come into public office, and to lead and to serve.  Public service is an honourable duty, with intrinsic rewards.

 

     Some go further and argue that by comparing salaries of officer holders in this way, it undermines the whole concept of service and the moral authority of Ministers.  As I said earlier, it is an inverse relationship -  the more the salary, the less the moral authority, and the less the salary, the higher the moral authority.

 

     I think this is not the correct way of thinking about it.  What is most important is the motivations of the person and his willingness to devote his time and energies to serving and to making a difference.  If a person is motivated by money, then even a low salary has its dangers.

 

     As pointed out by Mr Alvin Yeo, if the motivation is money, there are more effective and less public ways of using one's position to make money than to have an open debate on salaries, as we are having in Parliament.

 

     Sir, I was rather disappointed by Mr Low Thia Khiang

 

 

who said that it was a waste of time and money to have such a debate in Parliament.   But, Sir, this debate shows precisely how transparent the Government is.  We are even prepared to come forward, speak in this House, have it debated publicly on a subject which can be as emotive and as personally discomfiting as discussing salaries. So I am somewhat disappointed with Mr Low that he is actually against such transparency.  Would he prefer a system where Ministers and civil servants’ salaries are a murky secret?  Ms Denise Phua should be assured that it is by this very transparency, that we make sure what she called the "nexus of power and money" will not arise in Singapore because we present what we do openly and transparently.  It is for the people to see and judge.  It is where there is no such transparency where politicians may take a pittance but actually amass a fortune that we need to be most concerned about the nexus of power and money.

 

     But back to the subject of moral authority. The key lies in how we make sure that the people who serve are motivated by the desire to serve and to do their best for the country and our people. The key is in choosing the right people.

 

     The approach we take is a practical one. In the last election, the Prime Minister asked me to help induct new candidates for the People's Action Party into this House and I am glad to see that many of them are now making substantive contributions in this House, in their constituencies to their constituents, serving them, doing good work for them.  When I asked them to come in, personally I knew that I was asking each one of them to make a sacrifice.  Those who were prepared to come in have come in, agreed to do so and they never talked to me about it, they did not mention it to me but I could see the doubts, the concerns, that little flicker in the eye where it said, "Is this really what I'm going to do?  Is this what I'm getting into?"  Some had to give up their jobs, they had mortgages.  But what I could see was they were most concerned about the family, "Will I have time for my wife, my husband, my children, to look after my ageing parents?" and then the uncertainty – would they be able to make good MPs, to live up to the expectations of the public, to live up to the expectations of the people that they hope to serve and the privacy they would lose because any shortcomings or failures would be exposed in a most public way possible.

 

     We looked for people who have shown commitment and concern for their fellow men. A good number had already been active in the community, in NGOs, before we fielded them.  Ms Denise Phua is one of them.  Mr Lim Biow Chuan himself served many years in the grassroots.  We asked them to come in and take on even heavier commitments and responsibilities in serving the people.

 

     The sacrifices that they make when they decide to become MPs and office holders are real and unquantifiable. We cannot do much about reducing these. But what we can do is to reduce the financial sacrifices so that we reduce some of the impediments that might otherwise make it more difficult for good men and women to serve, and to make a difference for Singapore and Singaporeans.


     Ultimately, the choice is made by Singaporeans themselves at the General Elections, every five years. And the people have chosen wisely. They have rejected candidates who offer themselves, with doubtful capabilities and motivations, and selected good ones.

 

     That is one level of checks. But the PAP itself has another level of checks. We screen, test and select our candidates carefully and one of the key qualities that we look for is the willingness to serve the people.  If his motivations are self-serving or to make money, we do not select him. And if we discover that that is what he is about after he has come in, we drop him.  One can only hope that Mr Low has equally stringent processes for selecting the persons they offer as candidates to the people because if you do not have transparency and you do not have discussion in this House, as we have been doing these last few days, we cannot be sure that the people that we bring into the office are the right ones.

 

     Now, let me deal with some of the issues on benchmarks.  Many MPs have spoken on this - Mr Inderjit Singh, Mr Gautam Banerjee, Mr Low Thia Khiang, Mr Lim Biow Chuan, Mr Alvin Yeo, Mrs Josephine Teo, Mr Chiam See Tong, Dr Loo Choon Yong, Ms Denise Phua.  Some have suggested pegging the pay to levels of government officials in other countries, taking a moving 3-5 year average, job sizing and scoping, including new categories of jobs, defining a new benchmark based on companies by market capitalisation.  Mr Inderjit Singh has also suggested there is really no need for a benchmark.  The Prime Minister should just decide and that would solve the problem. 
 

     Sir, in 2000, the formula for the MR4 benchmark was revised to make it more robust. We moved the Ave24 to 2/3M48.  And we took in half of stock options, not the full amount, in order to reduce the volatility.  We increased the numbers to eight persons in the six professions and we moved to the median, instead of the mean, to take care of this outlier problem.

 

     The rank positions of the MR4 benchmark among the top 1,000 earners have been remarkably stable and this shows that the benchmark is quite robust.  The rank position of the MR4 benchmark for YA1999 was 206th and in YA2006, it was 201st - remarkably stable.

     The benchmark formula, as I said, has been designed to take care of outliers and that is why we have taken the median in the six professions and we have also applied a one-third discount.  The median is $3.3 million.  The one-third discount brings it to the benchmark number of $2.2 million.

 

     Some have pointed out that the individuals in the group of the top 48 earners change from year to year. It is therefore unfair for Ministers to be paid according to this benchmark every year. I will ask for a table* to be circulated and this is a table on the 'dwell' rate of the 48 top earners each year.

     On average, for the last six years, on a year to year basis, close to 40% of the top 48 income earners remained in the top group of 48.  Specifically for lawyers and accountants, about two-thirds of the individuals remained unchanged (from one year to the next in this group).  Engineers stay the shortest in the list.  I am sure Ms Lee Bee Wah will have something to say about that.  No doubt they stay short in the list because when they get on this list, they grow up very quickly and become something else.  They are likely to become CEOs or take on senior management jobs in companies.

 

     Some Members have pointed out that if the persons change every year, then we are only selecting the top persons every year and it may be different persons on the list.  So that is not fair.  On the other hand, I can also see problems if the same persons remain on the list every year.  Then you can say that only these people are doing well and how about the rest of them who are not doing well all the time.  So when you look at it, a 40% ‘dwell’ rate, it seems to me to be not unreasonable but the more important thing is, what are we benchmarking against.  We are not benchmarking against specific individuals.  What we are benchmarking against is the typical salaries that persons holding these types of jobs and responsibilities do earn.

 

     We have selected these six job categories because they are realistic alternatives for persons who are considering a career in the public service, whether they are at a young age on graduation or whether they are considering coming into public elected office in their 30s and 40s because many of them are from these professions.  We have not included architects or doctors, because they require specific talents or skills, and we have not included entrepreneurs.  So entrepreneurs are not on the list.  Those who have made the point about entrepreneurs and risks, entrepreneurs are not there.  We can fine-tune the job categories - add in a few, put up, lose some, but I do not think the outcome will be very different.

 

     On Mr Alvin Yeo's suggestion to adopt a 3-5 year moving average, to some extent, we are doing this already, except that the average is very sticky - going up and very quick to come down when we move, because we move down very sharply during a recession.  I think it is very difficult for any government to say, "Well, the moving average tells me that I should stay there or go up when, in fact, we are in the middle of a recession."  So it comes down very quickly but it is quite sticky going up and, to some extent, I am taking a measured approach when we make these adjustments.  We are taking a longer term view of how salaries are moving already.  Mr Inderjit Singh suggested that the PM should  just decide and the problem is that we are having this debate because we have this benchmark but if the PM were to just simply decide and come up with a figure, he would still need to justify to the public how he came to this number, and he would have to find some means of comparison and benchmarking in order to have this number.

 

 

     Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I just want to clarify that I did not mean that the Prime Minister makes an arbitrary decision.  I was saying that we already have 13 years of a track record of Minister salaries and that we now have a base of $1.2 million and, now that we have a base, to implement a system of increments or deductions like any company, based on the base that you already have developed and well accepted.  It is not an arbitrary number.

 

 

     Mr Teo Chee Hean: So, in the end, we will still have to have some kind of benchmarking in order to have a basis for deciding what is a reasonable salary package.

     There were also questions raised, both in public and in this House, about what components go into the salary and what components do not go into the salary, that there is this very large figure that they have presented before them and there might well be other hidden extras which we are not aware of.  So perhaps I should ask for these other two tables to be handed out.  [Copies of tables distributed to hon.      If Members will allow me, I will take a little time to address the issue of pension.  The majority of civil servants are now on the full CPF scheme. Only the Administrative Service and Intelligence Service are on pension.  We have also earlier decided that the Senior Police Service and the SAF officers should also be on pension. The reason is that these particular Services require long-term development of the officers, deep experience in order for them to develop the expertise that is necessary in the area, and also to deal with issues generally of high sensitivity to our country.  Therefore, we felt that the pension component was useful and that we should have some long-term employment scheme for these officers.  The Police and the SAF are not on pension anymore, but they have changed to, what the Police call, an Invest Scheme and the SAF to a SAVER Scheme which is also a long-term employment scheme which encourages and rewards officers if they stay and serve loyally for a number of years. So the principle is something which we do want to maintain for these key Services.

 

     Given their role and impact, the Political Office holders also are eligible for pension provided they serve at least eight years as an office holder.  We believe that it is important to encourage people to serve longer periods of time so that they develop the instincts and understanding of how our Government works so that they can serve Singaporeans better. I should say that MPs elected after 1995 are no longer eligible for pension and all the salary revisions since 1995 have been non-pensionable in the civil service.  So pension benefits have been frozen at the 1994 level for each grade.

 

     Our aim in designing the salary package for our officers is to do so as transparently as possible, taking into account all remuneration components, in order to make as good a comparison as possible with the private sector.  Therefore, in principle, we ought really to take into account retirement benefits, such as pension, but we also have to take into account if we do that, whatever benefits of similar type, including full CPF, any kind of gratuity, termination benefits, and so forth, that may exist in the private sector.  This itself is quite a complicated exercise.  And in any case, if these benefits exist in the private sector, they are not reflected in the annual reports of income to the IRAS as well.  So they do not enter into those benchmarks that are in the private sector either. 

 

     But in practice, the salaries at MR4 have been lagging so significantly that retirement benefits, whether pensions or CPF, have not been a significant factor in previous salary adjustments.


     As steps are taken to close the gap with the benchmark, we will see whether it makes sense to take the superannuation benefits, both in the private sector and the public sector, into account. I think it will be quite a complicated exercise but we will have a look and see whether it can be done and how it can be done. 

 

     Let me deal now with this subject of benchmarking salaries of public officials to those public officials in other countries.  When Singapore is usually so obsessed with ranking and benchmarking on an international comparison basis - competitiveness, PERC, quality of government and public service, corruption index, and so forth - why do we not do so for Ministers and office holders as well? On the surface of it, it sounds like a very compelling argument. But you ask yourself, why are you doing these comparisons in the first place and are these comparisons valid?

 

     First of all, as I explained earlier, our salaries are clean.  Everything is there. So when you look at the salary of the Prime Minister of Britain, or Australia, or almost any other country in the world, you do not know what is the total compensation package.  You are really not comparing apples with apples.  We cannot find out exactly what it is that they are earning because it is not completely transparent.  That is one problem.  But the second and more fundamental issue is this.  Is that a relevant comparison?  When you do a competitiveness ranking with other countries, it is a relevant comparison.  Why?  Because you are trying to attract investors to come to invest in Singapore, to create jobs for Singaporeans.  So we want to see how competitive Singapore is against another country which is your competitor.  When you are looking at salaries for civil servants and office holders, you must look at what are the realistic alternatives that civil servants and office holders might pursue.  They cannot become office holders in Finland, Denmark, or the United States.  It is not a relevant market comparison for them, or vice versa.  You have to look at what a young man or a person in his 30s or 40s is comparing himself to - a young man or woman when he is deciding what he is going to do with his life.  And these are the relevant market comparisons, not what politicians in Germany, France, Finland, or Denmark are being paid.  It is not relevant.


     Many Members have suggested that we set up an independent panel to review and set salaries - take it out of the hands of this Parliament, take it out of the hands of the Prime Minister.  We do not have to deal with this issue which makes us all feel very uncomfortable. 

 

     In 1994, we had a panel, chaired by Mr Michael Fam, who was then the Executive Chairman of Fraser and Neave, and it comprised other private sector leaders. Its terms of reference were to verify that the IRAS data and calculations in the White Paper were correct, and to comment on the appropriateness of the Prime Minister's salary, taking into account the job scope and responsibilities of PM.


     The panel was satisfied with the data and the calculations used and we have since computed the benchmarks annually on the same basis. And incidentally, the annual IRAS data that we use for the benchmark computation is audited by the Auditor-General.


     But we now have more than a panel. In fact, we have a full discussion and debate in the House, as Mr Inderjit Singh reminded us because he has kept the cuttings from 1994.  We have done this in 1994 and in 2000. We have full transparency. 

 

     But, ultimately, even if you had an independent commission and it recommended a salary, somebody has to decide whether to accept that recommendation and implement it, and you cannot escape from the responsibility of making that decision. What happens if the number is too high? Do you just go along and say, "Should be all right.  Nobody should get upset because this was an independent panel that set it."  I do not think you will escape the same difficulties as we are having today.  You still need to explain how, why and whether it makes sense or not.  And the Prime Minister and his Cabinet have to decide whether to accept this recommendation or not.

 

    Indeed, in other countries, there are independent panels but, unfortunately, the legislature or the government does not have the will and determination to implement the recommendations of the independent panel because of the political pressures and the inability on their part to do so.

 

     And what if the benchmark level determined by the independent panel is too low?  The Prime Minister and the Cabinet still have to take the responsibility for running the Government, making sure that the civil service has got enough people, and so on.  And it still has to decide whether to accept that, even in the face of a civil service which is losing people. So, in the end, the Cabinet and the Prime Minister have to take responsibility and then go to the electorate at the elections and ask the electorate to decide whether the job that they have done has been good enough.

 

      Let me talk about the difference between the public and private sectors.  Mr Lim Biow Chuan, Mr Michael Palmer, Mr Teo Ser Luck, Dr Lim Wee Kiak, Dr Loo Choon Yong, Ms Denise Phua have spoken a lot about the difference between the private sector and the public sector, particularly where it applies to risks. I think I explained earlier that the benchmark does not contain entrepreneurs and people who own companies.  So, basically, it is people who earn incomes and particularly the 15P32 benchmark contains the 32-year-olds who are working for others.  In that sense, it is not that different from a good Administrative Officer working in the public service.

 

     I completely agree with Members who say that if we are going to pay competitive market salaries, then we should adopt market policies in our performance management and HR policies in the civil service. And certainly, that is the way we are going to go, and that is the way we have been moving for the last 10-12 years. 

 

      Those of you who were in the House when Mdm Halimah spoke, I think she gave an excellent speech which described the HR practices that we have in the public service today, which are very different from the HR practices 10-12 years ago, and it was a very good speech, as Mdm Halimah usually gives, from the perspective of the workers who now face these new pressures in the civil service which they did not face before - performance bonuses, annual assessments, risks of having their whole function best sourced if they are inefficient, being invited in for polite conversations to tell them that they might find it more advantageous for themselves to continue another career in another line in the private sector, and not in the Government sector. The fact is that many of our officers now are employed initially on contracts and they have to prove themselves before they are put on permanent service.  These are now features of the public service in Singapore.

 

     On developing KPIs for public servants, we have been spending a lot of time talking about the Administrative Officers.  But actually, there is a wider public service out there, as Mdm Halimah pointed out, there are over 60,000 public servants and also statutory board employees who serve in the wider public service.  As Mr Teo Ser Luck pointed out, you can actually select KPIs for different groups of people, depending on what kind of performance you want from them.  Certainly, those frontline agencies, like EDB, who go out and chase for investments to come to Singapore, EDB incentivises them that way. That is one example.

 

     We have different benchmarks for different levels and different types of officers in the service. We also have different ways of rewarding our officers. 

 

 

The senior officers in the service have a larger component of performance bonus, and the performance bonus is both on an individual as well as GDP basis, whereas the junior officers, while they do have performance bonus, their performance bonus is generally a smaller percentage of their total annual remuneration.  For very senior civil servants, as I pointed out, the variable component is now 47% of pay.  Mr Alvin Yeo, I believe, and Mr Gautam Banerjee also suggest moving it up to 60% to 70%.  I am not sure whether we will get there eventually, but we are certainly moving in the right direction.  We have moved from one-third to half.  Mr Alvin Yeo says we should go to two-thirds. As we restructure the salaries, as we have the opportunity to do so, we will see whether this makes sense for us.

 

     One example of restructuring the salaries is also at the junior levels.  One of the reasons why we have given out the performance-based payment for our junior officers is because we want to take this opportunity to build up the performance element among our junior officers in the civil service.  And if the economy and salary levels permit in the coming year, we will take this performance-based payment and build it into the scheme so that it becomes part of the salary structure of our junior officers with a larger performance element.

 

     There have been many suggestions on what we can include into the matrix for deciding on the performance bonuses of Ministers and top civil servants.  We have considered a number of different possibilities.  None of the suggestions really is new, whether it is inflation, lower or average wage levels or whatever it is.  None of these suggestions really is new.  But the Government as a whole has to cater not just to individual groups of Singaporeans but also to all Singaporeans.  Therefore, we felt that the GDP is a good indicator of being able to create wealth for all of Singapore and, with that wealth, to be able to make, even those Singaporeans who may not directly benefit from that GDP growth, those Singaporeans even better off as well, as this Government has done consistently over the years through asset enhancements and wealth transfers. 

 

     I should also note that even the private sector, not just the public sector, also has difficulties defining KPIs to make sure that there is no distortion between short-term and longer-term goals of the organisation.  This is because if you have a KPI that is very focused on your quarterly returns, you may run the company into the ground over the five-year period time-frame to produce good quarterly returns for the next two or three quarters.  That has happened in companies.  And in Government, many of the things we do are very, very long term.  Some Members would have read the Straits Times' article where they interviewed Mr Tan Gee Paw, the Chairman of PUB, and he was quoted as saying:  "Some of the things we do in Government, we do not see the result within our own career."  The results come after we have finished our career.  Those are some of the types of things which senior public officers in the civil service have to deal with.

 

     So I would be a little careful about defining KPIs which are too specific, too targeted and too short-term.  But the Prime Minister decides on the performance bonus, and I am sure that, when he decides on what performance bonus to give to the Ministers, he will look at how the Minister and his Ministry are performing and take that into consideration.

     Let me now deal with some more mundane matters - mundane perhaps for some Members here but certainly matters I think very close to the heart of Mdm Halimah as well - ie, performance and career management in the civil service.  So I hope that Members will bear with me if I take a little bit of time to explain some of these details. 

 

     We have focused most of our discussion on Ministers and Administrative Officers.  There is actually a wider civil service out there whom we all depend upon to service Singaporeans and the public.  We must take care of all of them as well, because they serve loyally and faithfully.  I would like to thank Mdm Halimah for her compliment on the civil service and that it has come a long way, and I would like to reiterate that we value all civil servants, not just the Administrative Officers.  Like Mdm Halimah said, civil servants no longer enjoy secure tenure.  We have an exit route for under-performers and organisational renewal schemes.  Even our top public sector officers have fixed tenures.  Those who are on the Public Service Leadership Scheme have a 10-year tenure if they are at Deputy Secretary level, and then, if they make it to Permanent Secretary, 10 years.  After that, they leave.  So they are not there all the time, permanently.  As someone said, perhaps we should change the name "Administrative Officer", because it does not correctly reflect what an Administrative Officer does.  Perhaps, we should change the name "Permanent Secretary" too, because the Permanent Secretary is not there permanently. 

 

     I do freely admit that the civil service can do better in its human resource management and, in particular, its performance management.  I think all of us are very Asian.  The idea of calling in your subordinate and telling him all of his strong points is not so much of a problem, but telling him all his weak points, that is more of a problem.  So everybody thinks he is doing fine and, if he does not get his performance bonus, he wonders why.  As we have introduced the performance bonuses and more promotional grades in the various schemes and services, HR managers, in fact all managers in the public service, have to become better managers of people, to learn how to lead, motivate, reward them and tell them how they are doing, so that they can help to develop them.  So PSD will certainly examine how to improve the supervisory skills in the service so that they in turn can coach and mentor other officers better. 

 

      We have a rigorous regular appraisal system.  It is not just by the immediate superior.  But we have a ranking system where the officer is also considered by superiors of other staff of similar grade so that there is comparison between departments.  So it is not just on the whims and fancies of one superior officer that the fate of a civil servant gets decided.  There are quotas for performance grading so that you cannot have everybody good or very, very good.  You cannot have the entire organisation very good.  I was told by someone - I will not mention which uniformed organisation this is and in which foreign country - that, in his navy, 95% of his officers are performing above average.  There is obviously a problem there somewhere. 

 

     I agree with Mr Siew that we should be more transparent in how Administrative Officers are managed.  In fact, we do counsel and out-manage Administrative Officers who are not performing well.  May I ask for this other table to be circulated?  [Copies of table* distributed to all hon. officers in the Corporate Support Scheme and related schemes with the objective of examining and redesigning these jobs so that the officers can do higher value work.  We hope that this would result in greater motivation and job satisfaction for these officers. We are very glad that we would be able to work hand-in-hand with the unions on this.

 

     Mdm Halimah also mentioned one group of employees in the public sector. These are the daily-rated employees (DREs).  Our DREs today are now entirely employed by the statutory boards.  Most of them are in the National Environment Agency (NEA).  The NEA, which employs the vast majority of our DREs, has training incentives for them to upgrade themselves as part of the new Collective Agreement (CA) that was signed in October 2006.  They will receive a training incentive of $200 (per course) for completing and passing courses that lead to a nationally recognised certificate, and they can receive up to two such incentives a year. This encourages them to improve themselves so that they can do better.  

 

    There is also a Good Conduct Allowance which has been increased from $30 to $40 per month to encourage them to come regularly and to reward those who do not absent themselves from work. This was increased with effect from October 2006.  NEA also has plans to conduct a salary review of its DREs.  This is intended for implementation in the later part of this year. 

 

   Sir, I do agree that we do need a more holistic human resource management system in the civil service. Pay is not the cure for everything, and the civil service knows and realises that.  There are other deeper issues that we have to deal with. That is why, in conjunction with the pay increases, we are also conducting reviews of a few key services, for example, the Management Executive Scheme and the Management Support Scheme. 

 

    The civil service will also look into tapping and developing leadership potential across the public sector.  It is not confined to the top echelon of officers and includes senior officers in our professional and departmental services.  Young officers and other services with potential and drive will be provided more opportunities to stretch and grow them.

 

     Our system is not designed to keep everyone in the service.  So, we do not look for zero resignation and zero attrition, but we do want to make sure that we do not fall into the same position that we were in in the 1990s where, with a galloping economy, we were losing many people from all segments of the public service.  What it meant was that the level of service to Singaporeans fell. Those who remained in the service were demoralised because they had to do more work and they saw their colleagues leaving.  And because the service level fell, they had more complaints from the public, and I am sure, from Members of Parliament, about the quality of service and we were put under more pressure.  So we do not want to find ourselves in that same kind of situation.  We want to make sure that we can continue to remain competitive and we can keep, employ and retain our public servants and have a good working climate in our institutions and organisations. 

 

     Let me now deal with timing and whether or not this is a good time or right time to do this.  Sir, I have been asked whether this is a good time to make such salary adjustments.  But, actually, the point is that such salary adjustments must be done in good time.  Otherwise, we will end up with problems in the public service.  We have had no major adjustments since 2001.  We have already waited for six years. Economic recovery has been going on for the last three years and we have had good growth for three years, but we have not raised salaries as quickly as we should have.  If we wait too long and we are too far out of line, it makes it even more difficult to move our salaries because each time we do that, there will be consternation with the huge percentage which we are raising salaries by if we have to move once in a very long time to come to market levels.  In the long term, I believe that will be to the detriment of Singapore and Singaporeans. 

 

     There have also been many speeches and views brought up Members of Parliament and also members of public about the income gap and the difficulties of the lower-income group and those with no income.  Capping the salaries of Ministers and top civil servants will not solve this problem.  The problem can be best addressed  -  how to help low-wage workers, how to help the lower income and how to help the aged with no families through sound policies and programmes like those which were introduced in the Budget recently - Workfare, increased allocations for ComCare but, most importantly, through growing the economy, creating jobs, creating the resources so that we can help everyone in Singapore to lift themselves up and have a better life. 

 

     We have paid attention to the needs of the low income through the GST offset package so that over the next five or six years, they will be well taken care of. For those in the lower-income groups, the GST offset is worth some 16 to 19 years of the extra GST that these low-income Singaporeans will have to bear.

 

     On public assistance, there was a debate in this House with Dr Lily Neo during the Committee of Supply.  Minister Vivian Balakrishnan summed up that we want an approach that is low in entitlement, but high in flexibility, because the needs of these individuals are quite different, and we need to find more holistic and flexible ways of looking after their needs.  Indeed, I must say that Dr Lily Neo is a good example of a Member of Parliament who has, through her ingenuity and active involvement with the older people in her constituency, found these creative and more meaningful ways of helping them because they know that this is not the anonymous hand of Government that is giving that assistance, but it is real people with real hands and warm hearts who are helping them.

 

    Sir, I would ask now for this article to be circulated.  [Copies of article distributed to hon. Members.]  It is an article by Steven Bartos.  He is the Director of the Institute of Governance in the University of Canberra. This article appeared in this magazine called the "Public Sector Informant", February 2006.  The article looked at Singapore's public service as a possible benchmark for Australia.  The Australian public service is held generally in quite high esteem.  Bartos acknowledged that "Singapore had overtaken Australia in the efficiency and effectiveness of its public service".  He explained the reasons for this.  He said that we have revamped our processes, we have very creative and active use of information technology and we have reorganised our institutions.  He said that it took 300 people to draw up the Australian budget and 20 in Singapore.  I have not actually gone to the Ministry of Finance to count the numbers but that was what he reported in the article approvingly.  And very tellingly, this was what he said, and I quote, "The other source of Singapore's public service advantage is the extent to which it has invested in public servants themselves.  The senior ranks are very well paid, which of course helps.  Just as important is their investment in education.". He has many other comments to make about Singapore and the cultural differences and why we do things here, like banning chewing gum, which will be unacceptable in Australia, and so forth.  All in all, a balanced and thoughtful article - someone who understands Singapore and obviously knows what it takes to build a good public service.  And he quite ruefully said that the senior ranks are very well-paid, which of course helps.  I think that is a very understated way of making a very important point.


     Sir, I listened carefully to what Mr Chiam See Tong had to say yesterday. He said that we are just a little dot. When we look at America, it is 15,000 times our size and 60 times the population of Singapore.  He said that we are just a dot. America is such a big country, so many people, such a huge country and the American President is paid so little. What is so special about Singapore?  But, Sir, that is precisely the point. There are many, many dots in the world.  But what makes this dot so special?  This little red dot is very special because all of us have taken the trouble to take care of it very well.  All Singaporeans have worked hard to make Singapore special. The Government is a special government, carefully constructed, bringing in the best people so that it can move Singapore forward even with all the disadvantages that we have - the lack of resources, the position that we are in the region and the world. And Singapore is helped along by a first-class, excellent, efficient, uncorrupt public service that helps it to achieve Singaporeans' dreams.  

 

   Sir, we do need a good public service in Singapore.  It is a very special country, a very special red dot, Mr Chiam. We do want to make it even better for Singaporeans in the future. We need thinkers, planners and doers in the whole public service.  The whole public service has to work as a team and it has to work as a team with all Singaporeans.   We have a public service that we can be proud of.  We have a Government that works.  It is a Government that works for Singapore and Singaporeans. [Applause.]
